head.title: Compressed Data; Bill on E-Signatures Moves Toward Approval

hedline.hl1: Compressed Data; Bill on E-Signatures Moves Toward Approval

block.p: Congress is expected to pass legislation this week that would make electronic signatures and records as legally binding as pen-and-paper versions. Passage would end a long stalemate over how far a law should go in freeing financial institutions from current consumer notification laws.

The compromise bill, approved by a House-Senate conference committee late last week, would confirm that electronic signatures and electronic records were legal. It would also provide a way for banks and insurers to notify consumers of late payments or changes in credit card or loan contracts via e-mail rather than postal mail, and it would allow financial institutions to begin keeping more records electronically.

Congress is expected to pass legislation this week that would make electronic signatures and records as legally binding as pen-and-paper versions. Passage would end a long stalemate over how far a law should go in freeing financial institutions from current consumer notification laws.

The compromise bill, approved by a House-Senate conference committee late last week, would confirm that electronic signatures and electronic records were legal. It would also provide a way for banks and insurers to notify consumers of late payments or changes in credit card or loan contracts via e-mail rather than postal mail, and it would allow financial institutions to begin keeping more records electronically.

The legislation incorporates a measure sought by the Clinton administration, requiring a company to conduct a test e-mailing with customers before sending any subsequent e-mail notifications. ''This is good news for both the Internet economy and American consumers,'' Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia and chairman of the House Commerce Committee, said.
